choices.text: Indirect laryngoscopy for vocal palsy
Serum TSH, free T3 and T4 level

questions.text: 2 days post total thyroidectomy, patient complains of peri-oral tingling. What would be the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Serum calcium level 

  • “This is due to removal of the parathyroid glands or infarction through damage to the parathyroid end arteries; often both factors occur together. Vascular injury is probably far more important than inadvertent removal.
  • The incidence of permanent hypoparathyroidism should be less than 1% and most cases present dramatically 2–5 days after operation; very rarely, the onset is delayed for 2–3 weeks or a patient with marked hypocalcaemia may be asymptomatic. The complication is limited to total thyroidectomy, as when lobectomy is performed the contralateral parathyroid glands are sufficient to maintain calcium levels.
  • In particular, total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection places the parathyroid glands and their vascular supply at great risk and should only be performed when there is evidence of metastatic disease or high risk of occult disease in the regional lymph nodes.” 
  • For mild hypocalcemia, oral calcium and severe hypocalcemia, intravenous Calcium gluconate are supplemented. 

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg. 866.

choices.text: Ligation of ITA away from the gland
Ligation of STA away from the gland
Ligation of ITA close to the gland
Ligation of STA close to the gland

questions.text: Which of these manoeuvres will prevent post op hypoparathyroidism in thyroidectomy (STA= Superior thyroid artery, ITA= Inferior thyroid artery)?
questions.solution:
Ans: C Ligation of ITA close to the gland

 

Truncal ligation of the inferior thyroid artery away from the gland can lead to hypoparathyroidsm due to ischemia. Both superior and inferior parathyroid glands receive their blood supply from ITA which arises from the subclavian arteries. Hence, during thyroidectomy, only the capsular branches closer to the thyroid gland should be ligated. 

 

Sometimes the parathyroid glands may have variable blood supply from thyroid-ima artery.

 

Reference: Gray’s anatomy: the anatomical basis of clinical practice , 41st edition, page 618 


Schwartz’s principle of surgery 10th edition, pages 1553-1554

choices.text: Emergency cricothyrotomy
Shift to OT and remove sutures of wound
Needle thoracotomy in triangle of safety

questions.text: After total thyroidectomy, in post-operative recovery room, patient experienced acute breathlessness and cyanosis. His O2 saturation dropped to 85%. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Shift to OT and remove sutures of wound 

  • “Haemorrhage is the most frequent life-threatening complication of thyroidectomy. Around 1 in 50 patients will develop a haematoma, and in almost all cases this will develop in the first 24 hours. If an arterial bleed occurs, the tension in the central compartment pressure can rise until it exceeds venous pressure. Venous oedema of the larynx can then develop and cause airway obstruction, leading to death.
  • If a haematoma develops, clinical staff should know to remove skin sutures in order to release some pressure and seek senior advice immediately. Endotracheal intubation should be used to secure the airway while the haematoma is evacuated and the bleeding point controlled.” 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 865.

questions.text: AGES, AMES, MACIS are all prognostic indicators of which carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Thyroid

Prognostic indicators of well differentiated thyroid cancers:

  • AGES: Age, Histological Grade. Extrathyroidal invasion and metastases, and tumour Size
  • AMES: Age (men<40y , women <50y),Metastases, Extrathyroidal spread and Size of tumours (< or >5cm)

MACIS scale (post op modification); distant Metastases, Age at presentation,(<40 or >40 years old), Completeness of original surgical resection, extrathyroidal Invasion, and size of original lesion in cms.

 

Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of surgery:10th edition, page no 1543

choices.text: Central part of hyoid bone and thyroglossal tract
Thyroglossal tract and part of thyroid
Thyroglossal tract and associated cervical lymph nodes

questions.text: A child with a midline swelling in the neck, has to undergo a sistrunk procedure. Along with en bloc cystectomy, what other structures will the surgeon resect?
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Central part of hyoid bone and thyroglossal tract

Sistrunk operation involves en bloc cystectomy with excision of the entire thyroglossal tract till the base of the tongue along with the central hyoid bone.  It is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal cysts. Aim of surgery is to prevent recurrence and malignant transformation.

The most common malignancy in a thyroglossal cyst is papillary carcinoma. In such cases, sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is done.

 

Reference: Schwartz’s principles of surgery 10th edition page no 1522

questions.text: A doctor uses this method to palpate the midline swelling in the neck. Choose the correct option.
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Crile’s method

The following image depicts Crile’s method of palpation. Here, the patient is asked to swallow, while the examiner palpates the gland with the thumb. This method is sensitive in detecting a slight enlargement of the thyroid gland or small nodules.

Other methods:

  1. Lahey’s method: the lobes of the gland are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the lobe laterally with the left hand and the lobe is palpated using the right hand.
  2. Pizillo method: employed only in patients with short necks, usually in obese patients
  3. Kocher’s method: done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

 

 

Ref: S. Das A manual on clinical surgery. Pg 378-380

questions.text: A 27 year old female underwent an FNAC for a discrete thyroid swelling. The report showed a Thy2 lesion. What is your inference?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Non neoplastic lesion

FNAC reporting according to the Royal College of Pathologists UK:

Reference: Bailey and Love 27th edition, page 805

Sabiston textbook of surgery 2oth edition, page 898

questions.text: A patient underwent a thyroid radionuclide scan. She consumed I123 at 7 AM. What is the half life of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 12-14 hours

The half-life of I123 is 12-14 hours. Both I123 and I131 are used to image the thyroid gland.

Reference: Schwartz’s principles of surgery – 10th edition page number 1529

choices.text: Sternal incision is always required to operate.
Most of the retrosternal goiters can be removed by neck incision
It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms

questions.text: Following options are a few statements about retrosternal goiter. Choose the correct statement.
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Most of the retrosternal goiters can be removed by neck incision

Most of the retrosternal goiters  can be removed by neck incision (transcervical.)

Option A: median sternotomy approach is indicated in:

  • Primary mediastinal goitre
  • Malignant retrosternal goitre
  • Very large retrosternal goiter
  • Recurrence in mediastinum for a primary mediastinal goitre whose boundaries or completely within the chest, resection is often achieved through a median sternotomy or thoracotomy to ensure that the vessels supplying the tumour are properly ligated. Removing the tumour through a cervical approach can result in uncontrolled bleeding and is generally avoided.

Option C: blood supply to retrosternal goitre is from the thyroid vessel.

Option D: surgical removal of the retrosternal goiter is indicated in patients with significant airway compression, in young patients who have symptoms such as dyspnea or dysphagia.

 

Reference: Bailey and Love 27th edition, pages 810,811

choices.text: A 24 year old woman with FNAC report of Bethesda category 4
A 60 year old man with FNAC report of Thy2
A 15 year old with recurrence of thyroid cyst
A 66 year old man with positive Pemberton’s sign

questions.text: Patients present in your OPD, with the following reports. To which patient will you least likely advise surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. A 60 year old man with FNAC report of Thy2

FNAC report Thy2 is suggestive of non neoplastic origin and is not an indication for surgery.

Indications for surgical management of thyroid swellings are in the following:

  • Neoplasia: FNAC positive Thy3-5 and clinical suspicion
  • Age
  • Male sex
  • Hard texture
  • Fixity
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • Recurrent cyst
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Pressure symptoms
  • Cosmesis
  • Patient’s wishes

 

Reference: bailey and love 27th edition, page 810

choices.text: In the TE groove as it forms one part of the Beahrs triangle
At the level of the Berry’s ligament as it enters the larynx
As the nerve loops around the aorta
Under the tubercle of Zuckerlandl on the posterolateral position of the gland

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a thyroid surgery. Which of the following points poses the highest risk for recurrent laryngeal nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. At the level of the Berry’s ligament as it enters the larynx

Berry's ligament is formed by posterior condensation of the pretracheal fascia and is attached to the larynx. It has the highest risk for RLN injury.

RLN is a branch of the vagus nerve. On the left, it recurs over the arch of aorta, and on the right over the subclavian artery.

Beahrs triangle also known as the recurrent laryngeal nerve triangle is formed by the:

  • Common carotid artery
  • Inferior thyroid arteries

Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Reference: Bailey and Love 27th edition, page 801

questions.text: A 30 year old female underwent a retro-esophageal goitre resection. She was found to have ptosis and loss of hemifacial sweating. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Horner’s syndrome

 

The cervical sympathetic trunk is at risk of injury in invasive thyroid cancers and retro-esophageal goiters and may result in Horner’s syndrome.

 

Reference: Schwartz’s principles of surgery 10th edition, page 1556

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will FNAC not differentiate benign from malignant goitre?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Follicular

FNAC is not useful in the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma of thyroid as it cannot differentiate between benign and malignant follicular lesions. Tru Cut biopsy is used to differentiate between them as follicular thyroid malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion.

 

Other limitations of FNAC in thyroid disorders:

  • Can’t distinguish between follicular carcinoma and adenoma
  • Cannot differentiate between hurthle cell carcinoma and adenoma

Not useful in Riedel’s thyroiditis

 

Reference: Schwartz’s principles of surgery 10th edition, page 1544

Bailey and Love 27th edition page 818

questions.text: A 55-year-old hypothyroid female patient presents with a painless, hard anterior neck mass, which progresses over weeks to years associated with dysphagia. On physical examination a hard, woody thyroid gland with fixation to the surrounding tissues was noticed. How will you investigate further?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Open biopsy

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Riedel’s thyroiditis, which is confirmed by an open thyroid biopsy. FNAC is inadequate due to the firm and fibrous nature of the gland.

Riedel’s thyroiditis is invasive autoimmune fibrous thyroiditis where thyroid gland tissue is replaced by fibrous tissue. It is IgG4 related systemic disease characterised by:

  • Elevated serum IgG4 levels
  • Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate
  • Abundance of IgG4 bearing plasma cells

It is associated with other focal sclerosing syndromes including mediastinal, retroperitoneal, periorbital, retro orbital fibrosis, and sclerosing cholangitis.

Clinical features:

  • Occurs predominantly between 30-60 years
  • Painless, hard anterior neck mass
  • Progresses over weeks to years, to produce compressive symptoms like dysphagia, dyspnea, choking and hoarseness
  • Symptoms of hypothyroidism and hypoparathyroidism as gland is replaced by fibrous tissue.
  • Physical exam reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to surrounding tissues

Treatment:

Surgery, high dose tamoxifen and thyroxine replacement.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 872

choices.text: Ectopic thyroid in anterior sternocleidomastoid muscle

questions.text: Which of these represents lateral aberrant thyroid?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Level VI cervical node

“There is an extensive lymphatic network within and around the gland. Although some lymph channels pass directly to the deep cervical nodes, the subcapsular plexus drains principally to the central compartment juxta thyroid – ‘Delphian’ and paratracheal nodes and nodes on the superior and inferior thyroid veins (level VI) – and from there to the deep cervical (levels II, III, IV and V) and mediastinal groups of nodes (level VII)”.

 

Reference: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 850.

questions.text: Which is the most common thyroid malignancy that may be found in iodine deficient (endemic goitre) areas?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Follicular

Follicular thyroid carcinoma is most common in iodine deficient areas whereas papillary carcinoma is most common in iodine sufficient areas.

Other most commons carcinomas:

  • Most common primary thyroid cancer: papillary
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation: papillary
  • Most common malignancy associated with lymphatic spread: papillary
  • Most common malignancy associated with blood and bone mets: follicular
  • Most common malignancy associated with multi nodular goitre: follicular
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid stroma: medullary
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome: medullary
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis: anaplastic
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis: papillary

 

 

Ref: Bailey Ed. 28th Pg. 866-868

questions.text: A patient presents with a Thy3 lesion on FNAC. He was posted for hemithyroidectomy. HPE shows the following findings. What is your next step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Perform a total thyroidectomy

Capsular invasion seen in image confirms follicular carcinoma, hence total thyroidectomy to be done.

As FNAC shows Thy3 lesion, which is a follicular neoplasm, the frozen section of the excised specimen has to be evaluated. The presence of vascular invasion confirms follicular carcinoma.

Surgical management of differentiated thyroid cancers (DTCS) are as follows:

Reference: schwartz’s principles of surgery 11th edition page number 1651

choices.text: In follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy

questions.text: Radioactive iodine ablation of thyroid is an absolute contraindication in?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Pregnant lady with papillary thyroid cancer

 

It is contraindicated in pregnancy due to exposure of the fetus to radiation.

 

Therapeutic uses of RAI are:

 

  • In primary thyrotoxicosis after 45 years
  • In autonomous toxic nodule after 45 years, it is useful as remaining gland will still function adequately after RT
  • In follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy, if there are secondaries elsewhere in the body, as in bones or lungs, then I131 is given.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 862,870
